inventory.commentary: Note: alternate British spelling of this term is 'favour'

sense.name: a social gesture of kindness
sense.examples: Don't ask Jane for any favors, you'll regret it. He did it as a favor to me. He'll need to call in some favors from his congressional buddies.

sense.name: a state of advantage or benefit
sense.examples: The new tax law will be to your favor if you make less than $50,000 a year. The outcome was not in my favor. The court found in favor of the plaintiff. He was accused of showing favor to one of the players. (gave an advantage to the player)

sense.name: having approval or held in high regard
sense.examples: Those interior wall colors have fallen out of favor in recent years. The summer interns all struggled to obtain the boss's favor. The legislature is not viewed with much favor.

sense.name: a small gift or souvenir given to guests at a party
sense.examples: The children received candy and balloons as party favors. At midnight the guests broke open their Christmas crackers to get the favors inside. The wedding guests each received a small picture of the bride and groom as a favor.

sense.name: being an available sexual partner to someone
sense.commentary: FAVOR[+role][+event][+patient][+partner][+sexual] Note: idiomatic usage that occurs in the plural
sense.examples: The actress gave the director sexual favors to land the lead role in the film. The chauffeur granted sexual favors to the boss's wife.
